comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Other things such as the fact that the first car is dirty  and the chap in the trench coat is wearing goggles. It's a bit reminiscent of the 60's movie "Monte Carlo or Bust" in its' look.

The Circuit (originally called the Ulster Rally) didn't start until 1931 so it isn't that. There were a series of Trials held between 1900 and 1908 and I think this may have been a view on one of these. There were speed trials held by the Royal Irish Automobile Club in Phoenix Park in Dublin as early as 1903. Let's see if the RIAC can throw any light on the photo.

I thought it could have been something to do with the 1903 Gordon Bennett race but the location and dates are wrong!

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content:
I've come across this photograph in the NLI before and it is almost certainly the 1908 Irish Automobile Reliability Trials. I won't be in the RIAC Archive until next monday and will confirm it then. If so it would be (from memory) June and not January.

The Irish Reliability Trials were first held in 1906 and were a very important event. They attracted considerable 'works' entries from the manufacturers who advertised widely any successes they achieved in this event. The Trials were held from 1906 - 1909 sand agin in 1913. They were the forerunners of international rallies such as the Circuit of Ireland rally.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Thanks a million for coming back to us so quickly, Bob! Confirmation of the month would be excellent too, though I'm 99% happy this was 1908.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: From here: ucapusa.com/lost_marques_swift.htm "in 1908 Swift did just that, taking 999.2 marks out of 1000 in the Scottish Reliability Trials, making it three golds in a row in this event, which Swift claimed as the 'world's record for reliability'. A team of three Swifts was entered for the Irish Reliability Trials and triumphantly carried off three gold medals, the team challenge cup, and 2548 marks out of a possible 2550, a brilliant performance. "

Found this in Arrangements for To-Day (Irish Times from Thursday, 21 May 1908)
Automobile Reliabity Trials - Weighing in of Machines, Messrs. McLoughlin and Harvey's Yard, Dartmouth road.
Dartmouth Road is in Dublin. Were there "legs" of the rally held all over Ireland, or would this rally have been a practice run for the big event in Dublin?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
London Times, Feb 12, 1908
The Irish Automobile Club announces its intention of organizing a trial much on the lines of last year's event, but omitting to place so much importance on the question of fuel consumption. The completed rules are not issued at the time of writing these notes, but it is to be hoped that they are not so replete with formulae as those of the last trials

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Weighing drivers and passengers:- The Glasgow Herald of April 9th 1907 comments at length on the rules of the 1907 Irish Reliablity Trials(which did include Waterford in its itinerary) including quoting rule 31
"All vehicles required to have seating capacity for four must throught the trial carry, in addition to thr driver and observer, two passengers or ballast equivalent with persons equivalent carried to 616lb" That means that the two passengers combined must weigh 44st, or 22st each, a rather tall order, even for Ireland. What is meant, although ambiguously expressed, is that each such car must carry four persons, including the driver and observer, and that the aggregate weight of the four, with ballast equivalent if necessary, shall be not less than 616lb.
As for the 'formulae' mentioned in the London Times, the Glasgow Herald doesn't hold back
There are other rules equally loosely worded, but it is when they come to the formulae for the hillclimbs that the drafters of the rules shine most effulgently. There are six of these formulae occupying three pages, and they certainly present curious and interesting features.They are complex enough to bewilder a senior wrangler, and loose enough to satisfy the dictum of the late lamented Daniel O'Connell regarding the driving of a coach and four through the statute-book.
The complete article, including an example of an impenetrable formula, can be found here
